Chambers]] |successor2 = [[John McKinley]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1780|1|30|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Concord, North Carolina]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1827|4|24|1780|1|30}} |death_place = [[Matanzas, Cuba]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |spouse = |alma_mater = [[Washington and Jefferson College|Jefferson College]] |profession = [[Lawyer]] |religion = }} '''Israel Pickens''' (January 30, 1780 – April 24, 1827) was an [[United States|American]] politician and lawyer, [[List of Governors of Alabama|third]] [[Governor of Alabama|Governor]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Alabama]] (1821–1825), member of the [[North Carolina Senate]] (1808–1810), and North Carolina Congressman in the [[United States House of Representatives]] (1811–1817). ==Biography== Born in [[Concord, North Carolina]], Pickens graduated from Jefferson College (now [[Washington & Jefferson College]]) in 1802, studied law and was admitted to the bar. After serving as Governor, he was appointed to the [[United States Senate]] to fill the vacancy left by the death of [[Henry H. Chambers]]. He only served from February 17 to November 27, 1826, when the elected successor, [[John McKinley]], took office. In addition to politics, Pickens participated in the [[American Colonization Society]] and was interested in [[scientific research]]. He invented a lunar dial. Pickens died in [[Matanzas]], [[Cuba]] in 1827. He was originally buried in a family graveyard but his remains were later moved to City Cemetery, [[Greensboro, Alabama]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Political Graveyard: Hale County, Ala. |url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/geo/AL/HA-buried.html#cms01279 |accessdate=2012-03-09 }}</ref> ==References== * {{congbio|P000322}} * {{cite web |title=Israel Pickens |work=Alabama Governors |publisher=Alabama Department of Archives & History |url=http://www.archives.state.al.us/govs_list/g_picken.html |accessdate=2006-11-09 }} {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |title=[[List of Governors of Alabama|Governor of Alabama]] |before=[[Thomas Bibb]] |after=[[John Murphy (Alabama)|John Murphy]] |years=1821–1825 }} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{U.S. Senator box |state=Alabama |class=3 |before=[[Henry H.
